block.p: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.
MUSIC

BOONTON HIGH SCHOOL The Baroque Orchestra of Boonton will perform for the Annual Vivaldi Fest. Today at 3 p.m. Tickets: $10; $6 for students and older people. 306 Lathrop Avenue, Boonton. (973) 625-0459.

CAPE MAY CONVENTION HALL Cape May Music Festival. Ahmad Jamal, pianist-composer, will present a jazz spectacular. Today at 8 p.m. Beach Drive and Stockton Street, Cape May. Tickets: $20 for each concert; $10 for older people; $5 for students. (609) 884-5404.

THE CORNERSTONE Sarah Jane Cion Trio. Wednesday, 7:30 p.m. to 11:30 p.m.; Kenny Davern Quartet with James Chirillo. Friday, 9 p.m. to 1 a.m. John Cocuzzi Quartet with Vinnie Corrao. Saturday, 9 p.m. to 1 a.m. 25 New Street, Metuchen. (732) 549-5306.
GIRALDA FARMS Giralda 2000 Lawn Concert featuring the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra. Today at 6 p.m. Tickets: $10; $4 for children. Route 124 and Woodland Road, Madison. (973) 377-6622, ext. 14.

KASSCHAU MEMORIAL SHELL Bucky Pizzarelli, jazz guitarist. Tuesday at 8:30 p.m. Free. Wooster St. Trolley Jazz Band. Thursday at 8:30 p.m. Free. Veterans Field, Maple Avenue, Ridgewood. (201) 444-1776.
MINSTREL COFFEEHOUSE Kat Eggleston and Kate MacLeod. Friday at 8:30 p.m. Tickets: $5. Morris County Park Commission's Cultural Center, 300 Mendham Road, Morristown. (973) 335-9489.
MONMOUTH CIVIC CHORUS ''The Heavens Are Telling'' program. Thursday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $10. The Great Auditorium, at the intersection of Pilgrim and Ocean Pathways, Ocean Grove. (732) 988-0645.

NEW JERSEY PERFORMING ARTS CENTER The Chieftains and Los Lobos. Tuesday at 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $32 to $62.50. Prudential Hall. ''Absolut Sounds of the City 2000,'' outdoor music series. Thursday evenings through Aug. 31. Killian-Braham Latin Jazz Project, latin jazz; Skinbeam, psychedelic cowboy swamp rock; Mozayik, afro-jazz with Haitian roots; Crescent City Maulers, swing. Thursday, 5 p.m. to 10 p.m. Theater Square. 1 Center Street, Newark. (888) 466-5722.

OCEAN GROVE SUMMER CONCERT SERIES Through Sept. 9. ''Stars and Pipes Forever'' recital featuring Gordon Turk on the Hope-Jones Pipe Organ, with Michael Stairs. Saturday at 4 p.m. Free. ''Star-Spangled Sousa'' concert featuring the Allentown Band. Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $20 (reserved); $15 (regular admission). The Great Auditorium, at the intersection of Pilgrim and Ocean Pathways, Ocean Grove. (732) 988-0645.

PNC BANK ARTS CENTER Sting. Tuesday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $30 to $85. Phish. Wednesday and Thursday at 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $29.50. Jimmy Page and the Black Crowes. Friday at 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $33 to $87. The Who. Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $35.50 to $152. Britney Spears. Next Sunday and July 3 at 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $25.50 and $44.50. Exit 116, off the Garden State Parkway, Holmdel. (201) 507-8900.
PRINCETON UNIVERSITY RICHARDSON AUDITORIUM 2000 Princeton University Summer Concerts series, featuring Meridian String Quartet. Thursday at 8 p.m. Free. Alexander Hall, Princeton. (609) 258-5000.

RAMAPO COLLEGE Academy of Music Summer Festival. Through Aug. 6 Emanuel Borok, concertmaster of the Dallas Symphony, will present a violin concert of Vietnamese music. Friday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $25; $20 for older people; $15 for children and students. Berrie Center for the Performing Arts, 505 Ramapo Valley Road, Mahwah. (201) 684-7844.

SHANGHAI JAZZ Daryl Sherman and Dick Sudhalter, cornetist. Tonight at 6 p.m. Wooster St. Trolley. Wednesday at 7 p.m. Terry Blaine Trio. Thursday at 7 p.m. Diane Moser Trio. Friday at 6:45 p.m. and 8:30 p.m. Moe Morello Trio. Saturday at 6:45 p.m. and 8:30 p.m. No cover; $15 to $25 minimum. 24 Main Street, Madison. (973) 822-2899.

STANHOPE HOUSE 2nd Left. Thursday at 9 p.m. Tickets: $7. Billy Hector and the Fairlanes. Friday at 10 p.m. Tickets: $6. Swampadelica. Saturday at 10 p.m. Tickets: $6. 45 Main Street, Stanhope. (973) 347-0458.
STOCKTON PERFORMING ARTS CENTER River City Brass Band presents '' Star-Spangled Brass.'' Next Sunday at 4 p.m. Tickets: $18 and $24. Jim Leeds Road, Pomona. (609) 652-4527.
WEST SIDE PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH RIDGEWOOD ''Faces of Love'' with Linda Green, soprano. Tonight at 7 p.m. Free. South Monroe Street and West Ridgewood Avenue. (201) 652-1966.
THEATER

EATONTOWN PLAYHOUSE ''A Midsummer Night's Dream.'' Through July 9. Fridays at 8:30 p.m.; Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Sundays and 3 p.m. Tickets: $17; $16 for matinees; $15 for students and older people. 37 Highway 35 North, Tower Shopping Center, Eatontown. (732) 460-0100.
JOHN HARMS CENTER FOR THE ARTS Ray Romano. Wednesday at 7 p.m. and 9:30 p.m. Tickets: $22 to $42. 30 North Van Brunt Street, Englewood. (201) 567-3600.

HUNTERDON HILLS PLAYHOUSE ''Mary, Mary,'' Jean Kerr's comedy. Through Friday. Monday through Friday luncheon performances at 11 a.m., $35.50 and $39.50; today at 3:30 p.m., $41.50 and $45.50. Reservations required. Exit 12 off Routes 78 and 22, Perryville. (800) 447-7313.

LEONIA PLAYERS' GUILD ''The Crucible'' by Henry Miller. Through July 9. Fridays and Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $15; $12 for students and older people. Civil War Drill Hall Theater, 130 Grand Avenue at Oakdene Avenue, Leonia. (201) 947-9606.

McCARTER THEATER Opera Festival of New Jersey. Through July 23. ''Falstaff.'' Wednesday at 7:30 p.m.; Friday at 8 p.m.; Sunday July 9 at 2 p.m.; Saturday July 15 at 8 p.m. ''Carmen.'' Today at 2 p.m.; Saturday at 8 p.m.; Saturday July 8 at 8 p.m.; Friday, July 14 at 8 p.m. Tickets: $22 to $82. Center for the Performing Arts, 91 University Place, Princeton. (609) 258-2787.

MONTCLAIR STATE UNIVERSITY TheaterFest, the Professional Equity Theatre-in-Residence. Through August. ''Master Class,'' starring Leslie Uggams. Today at 3 p.m. ''Snakebit.'' Thursday through July 9. Thursday through Saturday at 8 p.m.; next Sunday at 3 p.m.Tickets: $35; $28 for older people. Valley Road and Normal Avenue, Upper Montclair. (973) 655-5112.

MURDER TO GO THEATER ''Killing Mr. Withers.'' Ongoing. Fridays and Saturdays at 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $45 on Fridays; $48 on Saturdays, includes four-course dinner. Il Giardino, Cedar Knolls. (973) 301-0562.
NEW JERSEY PERFORMING ARTS CENTER The Who's ''Tommy.'' Today at 3 p.m. Tickets: $12 to $58. Prudential Hall. 1 Center Street, Newark. (888) 466-5722.

NEW JERSEY SHAKESPEARE FESTIVAL ''The Forest,'' by Alexander Ostrovsky, Russian playwright. Through July 2. Today at 2 p.m. and 7 p.m.; Tuesday and Wednesday at 8 p.m.; Thursday at 7:30 p.m.; Friday at 8 p.m.; Saturday at 2 p.m. and 8 p.m.; next Sunday at 2 p.m. and 7 p.m. Tickets: $21 to $38. F. M. Kirby Shakespeare Theater, 36 Madison Avenue, Madison. (973) 408-5600.

PAPER MILL PLAYHOUSE ''Pippin.'' Through July 23. Wednesdays through Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Sundays at 7:30 p.m.; Thursday and Sunday matinees at 2 p.m.; Saturday matinees at 2:30 p.m. Tickets: $36 to $60. Brookside Drive, Millburn. (973) 376-4343.

PLAYS IN THE PARK ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum.'' Tomorrow through Saturday at 8:30 p.m. Tickets: $3; free for children under 12. Stephen J. Capestro Theater, Roosevelt Park, off of Route 1 South, Edison. (732) 548-2884.

PRINCETON REP SHAKESPEARE FESTIVAL Friday through Aug. 27.''A Midsummer Night's Dream.'' Friday through July 23. Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays at 7 p.m. Free tickets are distributed at Fleet Financial Solutions Center, 16 Nassau Street, Monday through Friday, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., and Saturdays, 9 a.m. to noon. Performances are at Pettoranello Gardens, Mountain Avenue and Route 206, Community Park North, Princeton. (609) 688-0381 or (609) 921-3682.

SPRINGLAKE THEATER COMPANY ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum,'' by Stephen Sondheim. Through July 15. Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays at 8 p.m. Tickets: $20; $18 for students and older people; $12 for children under 12. Community House Theater, Third and Madison Avenues, Spring Lake. (732) 449-4530.

TWELVE MILES WEST THEATRE COMPANY ''Inside Out'' by Adryan Russ Doug Haverty, directed by Lenny Bart. Through July 15. Thursdays through Saturdays at 8 p.m., Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $20; $15 for students and older people. (973) 746-7181.
MUSEUMS AND GALLERIES

AFRICAN ART MUSEUM OF THE S.M.A. FATHERS ''Eloquent Threads: The Language of African Costumes and Textiles.'' Through Dec. 31. Hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. 23 Bliss Avenue, Tenafly. (201) 894-8611.
ATLANTIC CAPE COMMUNITY COLLEGE Sally Erskine, one-woman show of paintings and prints. Through Aug. 18. Call for gallery times. Art Gallery, 5100 Black Horse Pike, May Landing. (609) 343-5040.

ATRIUM ART GALLERY ''Five Views,'' featuring landscape photography. Through July 21. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Morris County Administration and Records Building, Morristown. (973) 285-6120.
BERNARDSVILLE PUBLIC LIBRARY ''Stories in Paint -- People and Places Around the World,'' paintings by Cinder LeDell. Through June. 1 Anderson Hill Road, Bernardsville. (908) 766-0118.

BRION GALLERIES ''New Work by Oil Painter Cathy Lang.'' Through today. ''Alien Beings of Uncertain Origin,'' one-man show of monotypes by Stephen McKenzie. Through Aug. 27. Hours: Wednesdays and Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. 1293 Route 179, Lambertville. (609) 397-7030.

BRISTOL-MYERS SQUIBB GALLERY ''Fragile Dependencies: A Close Look at Delicate Relationships in Nature.'' Through Sept. 10 Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Route 206, Lawrenceville, three miles south of Princeton. (609) 252-6275.
CENTER FOR THE ARTS IN SOUTHERN NEW JERSEY Juried Art Exhibition. Through July 26. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. Jaggard House, 123 South Elmwood Road, Marlton. (856) 985-1009.

CERULEAN FINE ARTS GALLERY ''New Works,'' a summer membership show, with paintings in all media, sculpture and photography. Through Sept. 2. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 11:30 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays, 4 to 9 p.m. Headquarters Plaza Mall, Speedwell Avenue (Route 202), Morristown. (973) 267-3730.

CIVILIAN ''Val Sivilli: Paintings.'' Through July 15. Hours: Mondays and Wednesdays, 11 a.m. to 3 p.m.; Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. 10 Bridge Street, Frenchtown. (908) 996-7279.

COOPER GALLERY ''The Illuminated Woman,'' an exhibition of paintings and drawings by Eileen Kennedy-Dyne. Through Saturday. ''The Art of The Box,'' 10th Anniversary Gala Exhibition. Tuesday through July 29. Opening reception: Friday, 7 p.m. to 10 p.m. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, noon to 7 p.m. 295 Grove Street, Jersey City. (201) 451-1074.

DIVIANA ''Whimsy and Magic,'' a gala art show of handcrafted wall hangings by Mariette Van Hees-Theeuwes of Randolph, a Dutch-born artist. Through June. Hours: Monday through Friday, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. 1225 Sussex Turnpike, Randolph. (973) 895-2661.

GALLERY OF SOUTH ORANGE ''Suspended Animation,'' steel and bronze sculptures by Wendy Klemperer; ''Aspect of the Female Experience,'' concrete sculptures by Barbara Lubliner; ''Theater of the Moon,'' assemblages by Kimberly Maier. Through July 30. Hours: Wednesdays and Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. and 4 to 6 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 1 to 4 p.m. Baird Center, 5 Mead Street, South Orange. (973) 378-7754.

GALLERY ONE MAIN ''Summertime Hues,'' featuring members of the New Jersey Watercolor Society and members of the Garden State Watercolor Society. Through August. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Route 513, High Bridge. (908) 638-3838.

GUILD OF CREATIVE ART ''From F-8 to Beyond Nature,'' exhibition of digitally processed images by Alan Leckner and Dankwart Koehler, photographers. Through July 6. Hours: daily, noon to 4:30 p.m. 620 Broad Street, Shrewsbury. (732) 741-1441.

HUNTERDON MUSEUM OF ART ''44th Annual National Juried Print Exhibition'' and ''Artists of Hunterdon County'' exhibition. Today through July 30. Opening reception: today, 2 p.m. to 4 p.m. Hours: Tuesday through Sunday, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. 7 Lower Center Street, Clinton. (908) 735-8415.

JERSEY CITY MUSEUM ''The Prints of a Sculptor,'' by Melvin Edwards. Through Oct. 7. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Wednesdays, 10:30 a.m.to 8 p.m. 472 Jersey Avenue, Jersey City. (201) 547-4514.

JOHNSON & JOHNSON HEADQUARTERS GALLERY ''Windows and Beyond,'' exhibition of oil paintings by Sue Ellen Rohrer Leys. Through July 5. Call for appointment only. 1 Johnson and Johnson Plaza, New Brunswick. (732) 524-6957.
KESSLER INSTITUTE FOR REHABILITATION ''Walter Engel: Healing Wheels.'' Through July 15. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. 1199 Pleasant Valley Way, West Orange. (973) 243-6895.

LONG BEACH ISLAND FOUNDATION OF THE ARTS AND SCIENCES ''Foundation Faculty Exhibition.'' Through Sept. 6. ''2000 Craft Gallery.'' Through Oct. 15. ''Masks, Mirrors, Mobiles.'' Through July 5. Free. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. 120 Long Beach Boulevard, Loveladies. (609) 494-1241, extension 300.

MACCULLOCH HALL HISTORICAL MUSEUM ''Woven Into Words: Coverlets in America.'' Through Aug. 13. Admission: $3; $2 for older people and students. Hours: Wednesdays, Thursdays and Sundays, 1 to 4 p.m. 45 Macculloch Avenue, Morristown. (973) 538-2404.

MAKEREADY PRESS GALLERY ''Time Lapse,'' contemporary photography exhibit. Through July 8. Tuesdays through Fridays, 11 a.m. to 3 p.m.; Saturdays, 1 p.m. to 4 p.m. Gallery 214, 214 Glenridge Avenue, Montclair. (973) 744-8280.

MONMOUTH MUSEUM ''New Jersey's Pinelands: Water in the Balance.'' Through Sept. 3. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Admission: $4. 761 Newman Springs Road, Lincroft. (732) 747-2266.

MONTCLAIR ART MUSEUM ''Croquet: The Art of Play,'' interactive outdoor exhibit. Through Oct. 15. Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 7 p.m.; Sept. 9 through Oct. 15, course will be open Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $7; $4 for children. ''Untamed Spirits: Animal Imagery in Native American Art.'' Through July 30. Will Barnet: A Timeless World. Through Aug. 20. Hours: Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays and Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $4 for older people and students; free for members and children under 12. 3 South Mountain Avenue, Montclair. (973) 746-5555.

MONTCLAIR STATE UNIVERSITY David Cole: Recent Work and In Gathering of Paint Stirrers. Through July 21. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. University Gallery, Life Hall, Valley Road and Normal Avenue, Upper Montclair. (973) 655-7640.

MORRIS COUNTY HISTORICAL SOCIETY ''1900,'' exhibit of photos, products and objects. Through Sept. Hours: Mondays and Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 4 p.m. Admission: $4; $2 for students. Acorn Hall, 68 Morris Avenue, Morristown. (973) 267-3465.

MORRIS MUSEUM ''Contemporary Paintings From the Morris Museum Collection.'' Through July 24. Hours: Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m.; Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays to 8 p.m. Admission: $5; $3 for older people and children under age 3. 6 Normandy Heights Road, Morristown. (973) 538-0454.

NEW JERSEY HISTORICAL SOCIETY ''History's Mysteries,'' interactive exhibition. Through July. ''Dining In, Dining Out,'' featuring photographs, video clips, rare silverware, period furniture and 18th-century cookbooks. Through summer 2001. ''Pride of Newark: Baseball's Bears and Eagles,'' about the history of baseball in Newark. Through Summer 2001. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. 52 Park Place, Newark. (973) 596-8500.

NEW JERSEY STATE MUSEUM ''Forgotten Gateway: The Abandoned Building of Ellis Island,'' photographs by Larry Racioppo. Through Friday. ''Building a Collection: Fine Art at the New Jersey State Museum.'' Through Aug. 20. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 4:45 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Free. 205 West State Street, Trenton. (609) 292-6464.

NEWARK MUSEUM ''The Art of Ink in American 2000: International Contemporary Calligraphy.'' Through July 9. '' Shell Angelology.'' Through July 30. ''Year of the Dragon: The Calligraphy of Wang Fangyu.'' Through Nov. 12. ''Needless Necessity: Jewelry, Silver and Personal Meaning.'' Through December. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m.; Thursdays (after hours) until 8:30 p.m. 49 Washington Street, Newark. (973) 596-6550.

NOYES MUSEUM OF ART Inspired by Nature series, featuring ''Recreating Flowers: The Glass Wonders of Paul J. Stankard.'' Through Sept. 3 ''Capturing the Jersey Shore: Works of Anthony J. Rudisill.'' Through Sept. 10. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. Admission: $3; $2 for older people and students. Lily Lake Road, Oceanville. (609) 652-8848.

OCEAN COUNTY HISTORICAL SOCIETY ''Ocean County From the Explorers to 1950,'' featuring photographs, documents, paintings and objects illustrating the county's history. Through Oct. 31. Hours: Tuesdays and Thursdays, 1 to 3 p.m.; Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. 26 Hadley Avenue, Toms River. (732) 341-1880.

PRINCETON UNIVERSITY ART MUSEUM ''The Dawn of Maya Kings: An Early Maya Stela.'' Through July 30. Photographs by Barbara Bosworth. Through Sept. 3. ''Flora and Fauna in Chinese Painting.'' Through July 30. ''Yayoi Kusama: Early Drawings From the Collection of Richard Castellane.'' Through July 30. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Princeton campus. (609) 258-3788.

PRINTMAKING COUNCIL OF NEW JERSEY ''26th Annual Members' Juried Exhibition: Prints, photography, digital work, juried by artist Arie Galles.'' Through Aug. 26. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Saturdays, 1 to 4 p.m. 440 River Road, North Branch. (908) 725-2110.

RUTGERS UNIVERSITY - CAMDEN ''Spirit of the Mask'' exhibit. Through July 29. Hours: Mondays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Stedman Gallery, Third Street between Cooper Street and Benjamin Franklin Bridge, Camden. (856) 225-6350.

RUTGERS UNIVERSITY - NEWARK Prints and Drawings by Anaida Hernandez, 1989-1999. Through Sept. Hours: Monday through Thursday, 8 a.m. to midnight; Friday, 8 a.m. to 7 p.m.; Saturday, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sunday, noon to 10 p.m. Dana Library, 185 University Avenue, Newark. (973) 353-5900.

SOMERSET ART ASSOCIATION ''Reflections,'' works by William Nagengast, and ''Earth Prints,'' clay reliefs transformed into works on paper by Sy Shames. Through July 13. Hours: Mondays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.; Fridays, 9:30 a.m. to 2 p.m.; Saturdays, 9:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m.. 2020 Burnt Mills Road, Bedminster. (908) 234-2345.

SPRINGFIELD PUBLIC LIBRARY ''The Jersey Shore in 2-D and 3-D.'' Through July 13. Hours: Mondays, Wednesdays and Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 8:30 p.m.; Tuesdays, Fridays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.; Sundays, 1 p.m. to 3:30 p.m. Donald B. Palmer Museum, 66 Mountain Avenue, Springfield. (973) 376-4930.
TOWNSHIP GALLERY Kathleen Havens, paintings. Through July 7. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. Chatham Township Municipal Building, 58 Meyersville Road, Chatham. (973) 635-2482.
TRENTON CITY MUSEUM ''Hidden Truths: Bloody Sunday.'' Through July 23. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 3 p.m.; Sundays, 2 to 4 p.m. Ellarslie, Cadwalader Park, Trenton. (609) 989-3632.

WHEATON VILLAGE ''American Glass: 1900-2000,'' featuring more than 100 industrial and decorative pieces. Through Oct. 22. Hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $7; $6 for older people; $3.50 for students. ''HER,'' multi-media exhibit. Through Aug. 13. No admission charge to The Gallery of American Craft. Exit 26, Route 55, Millville. (800) 998-4552, extension 2756.
FOR CHILDREN
BARNES & NOBLE ''Darly the Dolphin and Friends,'' performed by Candy Nelson, children's singer. Wednesday at 10:30 a.m. Free. 1180 Raritan Road, Clark. (732) 574-1818.
FORUM THEATER COMPANY ''Pinocchio.'' Through July 15. Tuesdays and Thursdays at 10 a.m.; Wednesdays at 1 p.m.; Saturdays at 11 a.m. Tickets: $9. 314 Main Street, Metuchen. (732) 548-0582.

MORRIS COUNTY HISTORICAL SOCIETY Paul Peabody's Old-Fashioned Marionette Theater. Today at 1 p.m. and 3 p.m. Tickets: $.25; $.05 for children. The Carriage House, Acorn Hall, 68 Morris Avenue, Morristown. (973) 267-3465.

NEWARK MUSEUM ''Where in the Universe Is Carmen Sandiego?'' at the Alice and Leonard Dreyfuss Planetarium. Through October. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays at 2:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 1 p.m. and 3 p.m. Tickets: $3; $2 for members; $1 for children and older people. 49 Washington Street, Newark. (973) 596-6355.

STONY BROOK-MILLSTONE WATERSHED ''Exploring the Night: Firefly Parade.'' Tuesday, 8:30 a.m. to 10 p.m. Fee: $8. ''Tiny Tot Walks'' for children aged 18 to 36 months. Wednesday, 10 a.m. to 10:45 a.m. Fee: $5. ''Life in the Stony Brook'' for families. Saturday, 9 a.m. to 1 p.m. Fee: $10. Pre-registration is required. Buttinger Nature Center, 31 Titus Mill Road, Pennington. (609) 737-7592.

TRAILSIDE NATURE AND SCIENCE CENTER Planetarium Show. Today, 2 p.m. and 3:30 p.m. ''Mulberry Munchies'' wildlife tasting. Wednesday, 7 p.m. to 8 p.m. Pre-registration is required. Admission: $3; $2.55 for older people. 452 New Providence Road, Mountainside. (908) 789-3670.

WALT WHITMAN CULTURAL ARTS CENTER Fun Summer Fridays, through Aug. 25. Poetry Alive! Friday, 10:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. Free; donations accepted. Johnson Park at Second and Copper Streets, Camden. (856) 964-8300.
SPOKEN WORD
BARNES & NOBLE Arthur Lefkowitz, author, will discuss and sign his book, ''The Long Retreat.'' Wednesday at 7 p.m. Free. 44 Brick Plaza, Brick. (732) 255-5914.

BARNES & NOBLE Camille Cusumano, author of several cookbooks and a senior editor at the travel and food magazine ''VIA,'' will discuss her new book, ''The Last Cannoli.'' Cannoli will be served. 59 Washington Street, Hoboken. (201) 653-1165.

BARNES & NOBLE Diana Jackson will present a discussion on ''The Lucrative Job Search.'' Ms. Jackson is a colleague of Jack Chapman, author of ''Negotiating Your Salary: How to Make $1000 a Minute.'' Wednesday at 7:30 p.m. 160 Route 17 North, Paramus. (201) 261-6995.

ENGLEWOOD PUBLIC LIBRARY Ted Anton, associate professor of non-fiction writing at DePaul University, will discuss his new book, ''Bold Science: Seven Scientists Who Are Changing Our World.'' Tomorrow at 8 p.m. Free. 31 Engle Street, Englewood. (201) 568-2215, ext. 244.
ETC.

CHASE SUMMER POPS TOUR New Jersey Symphony Orchestra and the Chase Manhattan Bank sponsor four free outdoor performances, entitled ''An All-American Celebration.'' Wednesday through Saturday. Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., Echo Lake Park, Mountainside/Westfield; Thursday at 7:30 p.m. at Branch Brook Park, Newark; Friday at 7:30 p.m. at Brookdale Park in Bloomfield/Montclair; Saturday at 7:30 p.m. at Mercer County Park, West Windsor. (973) 624-3713.

MEADOWLANDS FAIR Featuring 70 rides, more than 60 food concessions and 100 games of skill. Through July 9. Hours: Mondays through Thursdays, 6 p.m. to 1 a.m.; Fridays, 6 p.m. to 2 a.m.; Saturdays, noon to 2 a.m.; Sundays, noon to midnight. Cost: $6 (Mondays through Fridays); $8 (Saturdays and Sundays); $3 for children under 12 (Mondays through Fridays); $4 (Saturdays and Sundays); free for children under 34 inches tall. Giants Stadium, Meadowlands Sports Complex, Route 3, East Rutherford. (201) 933-0199.

METUCHEN STREET FAIR AND JAZZ FESTIVAL Featuring Perception, jazz group; The Dixie Mix, dixieland jazz; Ear Candy, afro-Caribbean jazz; One More Once, electric jazz quintet; and Phoenix Rising, latin jazz band. Today, noon to 5 p.m. Free. Along New and Main Streets, Metuchen. (908) 996-3036.

NEW JERSEY INTERNATIONAL FILM FESTIVAL SUMMER 2000 ''Coming to Light: Edward S. Curtis and the North American Indians.'' Today at 7 p.m. Scott Hall, 123. Rutgers University, College Avenue and Hamilton Street, New Brunswick. (732) 932-8482. ''Song of Ceylon.'' Wednesday at 7 p.m. Borders Books, Mid-State Mall, 300 Route 18 North, East Brunswick. (732) 238-7000. Tickets: $5; $4 for members. NEW JERSEY IRISH FESTIVAL Entertainment includes John McDermott, recording artist; children's workshop, Irish-American Cultural Center Exhibition, large shopping village, food courts and more. Today, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. Tickets: $12; free for children under 10. PNC Bank Arts Center, Exit 116, off the Garden State Parkway, Holmdel. (732) 785-9039.

PATHMARK MULTICULTURAL ARTS FESTIVAL 2000 Elvis Classe and Su Banda Loca. Today, 12:30 p.m. to 6 p.m., St. Rose of Lima Church, Gray Street, between West Market and Orange Streets, Newark. Free. (888) 486-4656.

WATERLOO VILLAGE Garden State Craft Brewers Guild's annual festival, featuring 15 New Jersey brewpubs and microbreweries. Today, noon to 5 p.m. Tickets: $20; $15 for non-drinkers and for ages between 12 and 21; free for children under 12. 525 Waterloo Road, off Interstate 80, Exit 25, Stanhope. (973) 347-0900.
